_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Grammer Logistics, Inc. - Eagle Lake Transloading Facility complies with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) #58 (2017 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws/codes. If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the Polk County Fire Rescue as well as the Polk County Department of Emergency Management and/or LEPC, as necessary. Medical emergencies will require notification of the Polk County Department of Emergency Management.

Grammer Logistics, Inc. - Eagle Lake Transloading Facility is a butane transloading facility (specifically, railcar to truck tanker). This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the butane railcar storage and transloading system only.

Grammer Logistics, Inc. - Eagle Lake Transloading Facility complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) accident prevention rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119). This butane railcar storage and transloading system is designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's instructions. Railcars meet the U.S. Department of Transportation Federal Railroad Administration design requirements for pressurized tank cars.

There have been no reported butane related accidents or incidents reported since the facility began operation in September 2018.

In the event of an emergency involving Grammer Logistics, Inc. - Eagle Lake Transloading Facility butane railcar storage and transloading system, it is the policy of the facility to initially contact the Polk County Fire Rescue and request their assistance. The facility personnel are trained. Facility emergency response is coordinated with the fire department and Polk County Department of Emergency Management and/or LEPC. Polk County Fire Rescue is aware of the system and its avail

able fire protection systems (site fire extinguishers and emergency shut-off devices). The primary hazardous materials response capabilities are provided by Polk County Fire Rescue.

Improvement actions to be considered primarily focus on site security and rail safety measures including continuing safety audits and safety inspections.


Grammer Logistics, Inc. - Eagle Lake Transloading Facility is a butane railcar storage and transloading facility (specifically, railcar to truck tanker). This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the Butane Railcar Storage and Transloading Process (Program Level 3) including storage of up to 13 butane railcars (ten [10] n-butane and three [3] isobutane) and approximately three (3) transloading units.

This Facility complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) accident prevention rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119). This process is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's instructions. Railcars meet the U.S. Department of Transportation Federal Railroad Administration design requirements for pressurized tank cars.

There have been no incidents/accidents involving butane which resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuation or sheltering in-place in the previous five (5) years.

This Facility maintains and emergency plan meeting the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38. Operators and facility personnel receive initial training in the provisions of this plan and refresher training periodically. In addition, this plan is shared with the local responding agencies and coordination activities occur annually. For the purposes of emergency response, this Facility is considered a "non-responding" facility and personnel do not conduct offensive emergency response actions. In the event of an emergency involving the Butane Railcar Storage and Tran

sloading Process, it is the policy of the facility to activate the emergency shutdown system, evacuate all onsite personnel, and contact Polk County Fire Rescue and request their assistance.

Grammer routinely evaluates the safety and hazards associated with the Butane Transloading Process through regular compliance audits and process hazard analysis revalidations. When potential areas of improvement are identified, they are reviewed and action plans are developed to ensure the relevant measures are implemented.
